props.header: During extraordinary times, Emory School of Medicine is changing the way we think of medicine.
props.text:
Throughout the School of Medicine’s remarkable history, our objectives have remained the same: provide outstanding educational programs; develop excellent clinicians and investigators; conduct breakthrough collaborative research across disciplines; advance the detection, treatment, and prevention of disease; and ensure the highest ethical and professional standards.

By balancing each of these goals, Emory prepares students to challenge the conventions of traditional care, reshape how medicine is practiced, and promote the health of their patients and communities.
People here really want to work together. There’s a tremendous desire to work collaboratively, and this is what’s needed in order to tackle the toughest problems that face society today.
props.attribution:
— Vikas Sukhatme, Dean, Emory School of Medicine
Chief Academic Officer, Emory Healthcare

props.title: Create a Hub for Scientific Discoveries
props.body:
Emory University’s latest beacon of biomedical research, the Health Sciences Research Building II (HSRBII) will be a hub for scientific discoveries and entrepreneurial research. Investment in 2O36 will support this facility, providing laboratories for 130 principal investigators in many specialties. With a state-of-the-art building that reflects the school’s ambitious vision, we can dramatically increase our recruitment capabilities, bringing in the world’s leading scientists and scholars to help us transform patient care.

HSRBII will inspire connectivity, cross-disciplinary research, and collaboration, fostering innovation across a wide range of areas, from biomedical engineering and informatics to imaging sciences, brain health, cardiovascular medicine, child health, cancer, inflammation, and immunotherapy.
props.media_text: Investment in 2O36 will support this facility, providing laboratories for 130 principal investigators in many specialties.

props.title: Mastering the Art and Science of Medicine
props.body: In an era of artificial intelligence and other automated processes, physicians who understand both the art and science of medicine are increasingly rare. This is why they’re so important in medical education. With endowment funding, Emory School of Medicine will attract master clinicians to guide students with expertise and empathy. By teaching our students the art of medicine and the latest science, these master clinicians will ensure that new Emory physicians will provide effective, compassionate care.

props.title: Access for More Students
props.body:
Health care—both in practice and accessibility—must become more equitable. To that end, the Emory School of Medicine is committed to offering scholarships to students and trainees across all backgrounds, regardless of their financial situation.

By providing more scholarship opportunities, students will be able to pursue fulfilling and meaningful careers without having to prioritize specialties that promise the highest potential earnings. Thanks to 2O36, Emory School of Medicine will continue to be a leader in education, increasing access for talented aspiring physicians eager to keep our communities healthy.

items.title: Faculty to Fight Heart Disease
items.description: Emory School of Medicine will recruit 15 faculty members across multiple academic departments to tackle heart disease and heart-related chronic conditions through 2O36. Life-saving results will be achieved through collaboration between the Emory Clinical Cardiovascular Research Institute, the School of Nursing, and the Rollins School of Public Health—finding novel solutions, refining minimally invasive therapies, and leading clinical trials for promising new treatments.

items.title: Faculty to Take on Brain Health
items.description: With your support of 2O36, Emory School of Medicine will be able to recruit 15 top scientists and physicians to collaborate with the Emory Brain Health Center and Goizueta Alzheimer’s Disease Research Center. Together they will pursue cures for Alzheimer’s disease, Parkinson’s, and other conditions that can accompany aging and affect the brain.

items.title: Faculty to Pursue New Cancer Breakthroughs
items.description: Winship Cancer Institute is Georgia’s only National Cancer Institute-designated comprehensive cancer center. 2O36 will allow Winship to add 23 faculty members who will create new ways of thinking about every type of cancer and translate that knowledge into new discoveries for patients. Together, we can increase access to the most advanced treatments available, transforming the care experience.

items.title: The Power of Collaboration in 2036
items.description: With your support of 2O36, we can recruit three distinguished professors and seven professors for the Wallace H. Coulter Department of Biomedical Engineering. These faculty leaders will develop new strategies for improving health, curing disease, and creating practical solutions to complex problems.

items.title: Advancing the Study of Infectious Diseases and Immunology
items.description: 2O36 will support the recruitment of 10 faculty members to teach and conduct research in infectious diseases and immunology—further cementing Emory’s reputation in the field. Tangible outcomes include the creation of vaccines that eliminate disease, along with cancer treatments that allow the body to fight back and heal.

items.title: Funding for Now
items.description:
Supporting the Future of Medicine through Scholarships
To deliver the highest quality of care, Emory School of Medicine must recruit the best students and trainees from all ethnic, cultural, and experiential backgrounds—regardless of their financial situations.

Transform Education Models
2O36 will support a focus on entrepreneurial teaching, transforming existing education models into methods that consider infrastructure, space, and technology in order to dramatically improve clinical practice and health care, and attract top students, trainees, and contributors to our communities.

Bringing Simulation Learning to 2036
Emory will incorporate simulation programs into our methodology, improving patient safety and lowering health care costs.

Serving Communities in 2036
Investment in 2O36 will expand our community medical service and educational programs in order to advance disease prevention, create more accessible care and education, and foster excellent experiential learning opportunities.

Promoting Innovation in Teaching
2O36 will strengthen the Imagine/Innovate/Impact (I3) teaching awards to continue supporting researchers’ development of novel approaches that enhance the undergraduate and graduate medical education experience.

2O36 Awards Research
The I3 Research Awards program will provide opportunities for talented and creative physician scientists to create life-changing knowledge.

Pursuing Health Care Innovations
2O36 will create the space and ability to pursue health care innovations, recruit a diverse group of problem solvers, and focus on transformation in key areas.

Leading in Pilots, Initiatives, and Programs
2O36 will support promising research and accelerate the rate of medical discoveries that race against time for patients living with illness.

Putting Data to Work
2O36 will help us leverage the power of data to advance the quality of entire health systems, improve patient outcomes, and reduce costs.

Recruiting the Best in 2036
Supporting recruitment of world-renowned physician scientists through 2O36 will enhance the student experience and create an environment for these scientists to begin work immediately.

With 2O36, Research Initiatives Can Flourish
2O36 will increase immediate funding for projects, like medical breakthroughs, that could change the world.

Industry-Funded Research in 2O36
Increasing funding opportunities from industry partners through 2O36 will attract leading physicians and scientists to Emory School of Medicine and allow for more discoveries in health care.
